instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook pro retina 13 2015
threads.message:
Hi, 
the customer say before intermittent start, but now no boot, green led and pass to orange without battery, no fan.
i check this voltage
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16,30V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> = 16,48V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> = 12,57V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3,387V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3,415V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> =3,414V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,335V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,3332V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,39V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 3,34V
no liquid, the board is clean, what can i do?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook pro retina 13 2015
threads.message: Sorry i forgot to tell, some trace of something liquid near <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> but just between a pin 32 and <RESISTOR>R7279</RESISTOR> i clean it but no more thing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook pro retina 13 2015
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook pro retina 13 2015
threads.message:
Fan will never spin on these until warm as you should know by now.

Check traces and resistors around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook pro retina 13 2015
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=0V
i find <RESISTOR>R7613</RESISTOR> bad value, i replace it now OK but already no change. i check under microscope all the board i find nothing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook pro retina 13 2015
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3</SIGNAL> = 3,34V
sorry but i really not understand what do you want when you say check power cycling on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> it's <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_EN</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_EN_D</SIGNAL> or other.
Do you have an video who explain this measure?
thanks
